Introduction

Preseptal cellulitis, also called periorbital cellulitis, is an infection involving the soft tissues surrounding the eye.  It presents with unilateral eye pain, erythema, and swelling.  Although the infection is typically localized, prompt recognition and management are necessary to prevent potential complications, such as extension of infection into the posterior orbital structures (ie, orbital cellulitis).

Anatomy

The orbital septum is a fascial membrane that forms a boundary between the anterior and posterior orbit (

figure 1
).  It extends vertically from the superior and inferior orbital rims to the upper and lower eyelids, respectively.  Preseptal cellulitis involves the eyelids and periorbital soft tissues, which are located anterior to the septum.  In contrast, orbital cellulitis, a more serious infection, involves the extraocular muscles and orbital fat posterior to the septum.

Risk factors

Introduction of bacteria into the periorbital soft tissues can occur from:

  • Recent trauma or surgery to the eyelids or facial soft tissues
  • Insect bites or skin abrasions near the eye
  • Eyelid conditions such as meibomian gland obstruction (ie, hordeolum) or nasolacrimal duct obstruction (ie, dacryocystitis)
  • Upper respiratory infection, particularly sinusitis (due to the close proximity of sinuses to the orbit)

Additional risk factors include immunocompromise and poor hygiene.

Pathophysiology

Preseptal cellulitis often arises from direct inoculation of bacteria through traumatic injury or surgery, but contiguous spread of bacteria from a sinus infection is also possible.  The most common causative organisms are representative of the source of infection.  Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes are most common when infection originates in the periorbital skin (eg, abrasion, insect bite), whereas Streptococcus pneumoniae, Moraxella catarrhalis, and Haemophilus influenzae are more likely when preseptal cellulitis is preceded by a nasopharyngeal infection.

Clinical presentation

The following symptoms are typically observed in preseptal cellulitis:

  • Swelling and erythema of the eyelids
  • Tenderness and warmth around the affected eye
  • Fever and malaise (in severe cases)
  • Vision remains unaffected

Proptosis, pain with extraocular movements, and ophthalmoplegia (ie, weakness/paralysis of the extraocular muscles) are not consistent with preseptal cellulitis.  These findings are characteristic of orbital cellulitis, which involves the tissues posterior to the orbital septum.

Diagnosis

Preseptal cellulitis is primarily a clinical diagnosis, based on the patient's history and physical examination.  Imaging studies such as CT scan or MRI may be necessary in uncertain cases to rule out involvement of the posterior orbit.

In most cases, laboratory testing is not required.  However, if suspicion of systemic involvement (eg, high fever) exists or if the patient is very young or immunocompromised, blood cultures and a complete blood count (CBC) may be obtained to assess for bacteremia and systemic infection.

Differential diagnosis

  • Orbital cellulitis (
    image 1
    ):  a severe infection involving the extraocular muscles and orbital fat posterior to the orbital septum.  Both preseptal and orbital cellulitis cause eye pain, periorbital edema, and erythema.  However, proptosis, pain with extraocular movements, and ophthalmoplegia (ie, paralysis of extraocular muscles) are the defining characteristics of orbital cellulitis and are not present in preseptal infections.  Orbital cellulitis is also more likely to cause chemosis (ie, conjunctival swelling) and systemic symptoms (eg, fever, leukocytosis).
  • Allergic or contact dermatitis:  can cause eyelid swelling, erythema, and itching.  It is often associated with exposure to allergens or irritants such as topical medications or environmental triggers.
  • Hordeolum (ie, stye) (
    image 2
    ):  an acute localized inflammatory lesion of the eyelid caused by obstruction of the meibomian gland.  It typically presents as a discrete, tender, erythematous nodule on the eyelid margin rather than the diffuse soft-tissue erythema and edema seen in preseptal cellulitis.
  • Dacryocystitis (
    image 3
    ):  an infection of the lacrimal sac, often secondary to obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct (
    figure 2
    ).  Patients may present with localized swelling, erythema, and tenderness, but symptoms are often localized over the medial canthal region.  Excessive tearing is a unique characteristic of this condition.

Management

The majority of adults and children age >1 with preseptal cellulitis have outpatient management with 5-7 oral antibiotics; however, antibiotics should be continued until symptoms are nearly resolved.

Empiric therapy is directed against bacteria that colonize the common sources of infection, including the skin (eg, S aureus and S pyogenes) and nasopharynx (eg, S pneumoniae).

In patients with no recent injury to the periorbital skin, the presumed source is the nasopharynx and antibiotic options for empiric therapy include amoxicillin-clavulanate (first line), a second- or third-generation cephalosporin, or levofloxacin (for penicillin allergy).

Patients whose source is related to a traumatic break in the periorbital skin (eg, insect bite) should receive additional coverage for methicillin-resistant S aureus (MRSA) with either linezolid or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.  MRSA is uncommon in preseptal infections originating from the nasopharynx, which is why patients with a presumed nasopharyngeal source do not require MRSA coverage.

Hospital admission and intravenous antibiotics may be indicated in certain situations, including:

  • Children age <1
  • Evidence of severe illness (eg, high fever, toxic appearance)
  • Concern for orbital cellulitis
  • Failure of outpatient therapy

Prognosis

With prompt and appropriate treatment, the prognosis for preseptal cellulitis is excellent.  Most patients show improvement within 48 hours of initiating antibiotic therapy.  However, delayed diagnosis or inadequate treatment can lead to complications such as orbital cellulitis.

Summary

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection involving the periorbital soft tissues located anterior to the orbital septum (
